ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I thought that the course was very good. I think that Jonathan Weinberg is an insightful teacher who gives great feedback on writing. I also think that he was a very resourceful teacher who gave us good advice on research.
Greater insight into the art industrial complex and how it operates. A methodology of how to approach analyzing a work of art within its historical and social context.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think that the class was great because I was exposed to many different artists and works of art. I think that the class can be a little more discussion based.
Professor Weinberg often got off-track and we didn't complete discussion on most days as planned. That being said, the seminar room was often a fun and inviting space.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I'd recommend this course to someone who's very interested in the art world. I'd recommend it less to someone who's more interested in the craft of making art. It's more about the "Critical theory" part than the "in the studio" part.
Take it if you can! Great class. Weinberg is a bit lecture-y at times but it is always interesting and ends up being very worthwhile
I would definitely recommend the course to another student. You learn a lot about different movements in art throughout the course, and the readings are very interesting.

Yes, just based on the readings and the organization of the course into major themes. If you think you'll like it based on the syllabus, you probably will. If you've ever wondered about 20th-century art history, or tried to come up with your own theory of art and its evaluation, this will be a great experience. Also, Prof. Weinberg is pretty great, and always has useful insights and propositions to challenge your assumptions about art and art-making. In addition, as a nonbinary queer person, I found this class to be a more-or-less safe space to express and engage with that part of myself, which has been really rare in other art classes I've taken here.
